Its headquarters are at Broadcasting House in central London and it has 19 large offices in the UK and over 200 small studios, where its productions are made. The BBC is established under a Royal Charter and operates under its Agreement with the Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport. Its work is funded principally by an annual television licence fee which is charged to all British households, companies, and organisations using any type of equipment to receive or record live television broadcasts; together with equipment used for purposes such as time-shifting, video on demand, or similar TV services, subject to certain conditions; the fee is set by the British Government, agreed by parliament, collected, and kept by the BBC. the British Broadcasting Company, it was later reconstituted as the British Broadcasting Corporation in 1927. Its worldwide service began in 1932, and it incorporated independent radio channels into the existing service from 1967 onwards. The BBC is the world's oldest national broadcasting organisation and the largest broadcaster in the world by number of employees. It employs over 20,950 staff in total, 16,672 of whom are in public sector broadcasting.
